executive_summary: Rising awareness of mental health treatment's economic, personal and societal benefits has supported behavioral therapists in recent years. According to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Administration, one in four adults suffers from a mental health condition. In recent years, destigmatizing mental health has encouraged more of these patients to find a behavioral therapist.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Lifting Stigma Encourages More Patients to Find a Behavioral Therapist
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Millions in the United States are affected by mental health conditions each year. Mounting awareness of the importance of mental and behavioral health has led more individuals to seek behavioral therapy treatment in recent years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Behavioral Therapists Confront the Pandemic's Impact on Mental Health
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic disrupted traditional access to behavioral therapy as social distancing guidelines and practice closures restricted in-person treatment. While many adults faced mental health challenges before the pandemic, isolation and uncertainty exacerbated preexisting rates of mental and emotional health disorders.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Permanently Reshapes the Behavioral Therapy Landscape
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The need for behavioral therapy remains unprecedented even as pandemic conditions have alleviated. According to the National Alliance on Mental Illness, more adults reported symptoms of mental health conditions in 2023 compared with 2019.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Inflation Could Hit Healthcare Spending in 2024
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: High inflation and rising interest rates didn't dent spending on behavioral therapy in 2023. While the essential nature of treatment has historically shielded therapists from economic fluctuations, higher living costs could slow down spending in 2024.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: AN UNPRECEDENTED MENTAL HEALTH CRISIS TRIGGERS AN EVOLUTION IN BEHAVIORAL HEALTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Behavioral therapists' expanding role in treating the millions of people affected by mental and emotional disorders won't wane moving forward. Employers will continue to offer more comprehensive coverage of mental health benefits, expanding access to behavioral therapists.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: TELETHERAPY WILL ADDRESS PERSISTENT LABOR SHORTAGES IN BEHAVIORAL THERAPY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Behavioral health workforce shortages will continue to characterize the field. A limited pipeline of new professionals entering the behavioral health field will strain access, increasing the adoption of telehealth tools.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Behavioral Therapists Will Become More Integrated Into the Patient Journey
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the National Alliance on Mental Illness, mental health conditions cost the US healthcare system nearly $200.0 billion annually. Healthcare providers will promote behavioral health treatment as an integral care component to address swelling healthcare costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Teletherapy Will Grow But Face Reimbursement Challenges
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic will strain access, increasing the need for virtual options like teletherapy. Still, how Medicaid and private insurers decide to reimburse for virtual services will determine access to teletherapy.

industry_definition: Behavioral therapists are mental health professionals who specialize in the assessment, diagnosis and treatment of various mental health issues, with a focus on understanding and modifying behaviors. Therapists can work in an independent or group office setting.

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
threats: Number of People with Private Health Insurance

key_trends: A deepening mental health crisis has strengthened behavioral therapists' role. Even as the pandemic fades into the background, its impact on mental health continues to fuel an unprecedented demand for behavioral therapy.

Patients continue to seek behavioral health treatment virtually post-pandemic more than any other specialty. While relaxed regulations during the pandemic facilitated remote access to behavioral therapists, patients and providers opt for virtual sessions even after these flexibilities have ended.
A complex regulatory environment dictates how, where and to what extent behavioral therapists can practice.
Regulations concerning patient privacy and data security are in the spotlight as therapists increasingly go digital.
The pandemic exacerbated rates of mental and emotional disorders.
The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration is allocating billions in grants to mental health providers as people seek support in record numbers.
The pandemic expanded the prevalence and awareness of behavioral health issues.
Behavioral therapists are treating more patients than ever for mental health conditions but struggle to meet unprecedented demand.
Private payers are responsible for the bulk of reimbursements.
Private plans offer more robust coverage of behavioral health treatment.
Private plans pay higher rates for services delivered.
Behavioral health disparities separate rural and metropolitan areas.
Rural areas are facing critical shortages of behavioral therapists.
Therapists using teletherapy could offer a solution.
Population hubs support behavioral therapists.
Major population centers in the Southeast and Mid-Atlantic connect providers to larger patient and employee pools.
A sudden uptick in telehealth companies introduces a new type of competition.
Telehealth apps provide an affordable and accessible option for mental health treatment.
Pulls patients away from sessions with a behavioral therapist.
A fragmented behavioral health landscape creates a dynamic field.
Fragmentation pushes therapists to innovate and specialize.
Secure patient referrals in competitive, saturated markets.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Reimbursements from private payors include payments received from commercial health plans. Federal parity law mandates group health plans and insurance issuers that provide mental health benefits to cover them at the same rate as medical or surgical benefits.
Out-of-pocket payments include payments by patients or family members for any care not covered by insurance. This includes deductibles, copayments and coinsurance.
Government revenue sources include reimbursements from Medicaid and Medicare and grants or loans from federal or state agencies.

products_and_services.product_description: Behavioral therapists use techniques and treatments to help patients struggling with mental and emotional conditions (anxiety, depression, panic disorder, phobias).

products_and_services.product_or_service: Mental Illness and Substance Abuse Disorder Treatment
products_and_services.product_description: Behavioral therapists use several approaches to change an individual's behaviors concerning substance abuse. Substance use disorders (SUDs) result from repeated overuse of alcohol or drugs.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: COVID-19 exacerbates rates of mental health conditions
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for behavioral therapists has increased rapidly since COVID-19. The pandemic exacerbated preexisting mental health conditions following long periods of isolation and uncertainty, creating unprecedented support for stressor-related disorders, anxiety and depression.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Federal policies could extend the coverage of substance abuse treatment as PHE ends
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The end of the PHE in May 2023 will mark the end of regulatory flexibilities supporting behavioral therapy treatment of SUDs. How proposed policies expand behavioral therapist eligibility will determine SUD treatment access.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Behavioral therapy treats a vast range of conditions
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Behavioral therapy applications can apply to nearly every mental and emotional health condition for children and adults.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the US population resides in the Southeast region. As a central population hub, this area houses many behavioral therapy practices to address the needs of its population. As the third-most populous state in the US, Florida has the most practices in the region.

The Mid-Atlantic's share of clinics mirrors its share of the population. Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey are leading contributors to the share of establishments in this region. In a 2022 report by Mental Health America, Pennsylvania and New York ranked in the top ten states with the highest care access rates. New York has the fourth-highest employment level for therapists in the US. Densely populated New York and New Jersey metro areas influence the number of behavioral therapists in these states.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Anti-Kickback Statute and Physician Self-Referral Laws
regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits the exchange of anything of value (financial incentives, low rents, excessive compensation) to induce the referral of business reimbursable by federal healthcare programs. Physical self-referral law prohibits physicians from referring patients to a healthcare service if they or a family member have a financial relationship with that entity.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Mental health and substance abuse clinics must follow all of the criteria of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). HIPAA outlines controls for patient health data for any healthcare provider that stores, shares or sends private patient data.

The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) mandates audits of healthcare providers to ensure that they comply with HIPAA. The HITECH Act strengthens HIPAA by incentivizing providers to adopt electronic health records (EHR) and enforcing steeper penalties for noncompliance.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) makes payments to participating healthcare providers under its Medicare and Medicaid programs based on various formulas. Federal law mandates services hospitals render to Medicare and Medicaid patients to meet professionally recognized standards. CMS provisions also ensure that the healthcare services are medically necessary and reimbursement claims are correctly filed.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act requires insurers providing coverage of mental health treatment to make these benefits comparable to general medical coverage. The act also mandates that deductibles, copayments and coinsurance can't restrict access to behavioral health treatment.

basis_points.basis_title: A sudden uptick in telehealth companies introduces a new type of competition.
basis_points.basis_description: Telehealth apps provide an affordable and accessible option for...

concentration_points.concentration_title: NO COMPANY HOLDS A MEANINGFUL SHARE OF THE MARKET
concentration_points.concentration_description: Independent behavioral therapy practices (either a solo therapist or a few working together) characterize the market. Independent practices offering highly personalized care to local markets are a hallmark of behavioral health. Patient preference for these small, local practices has allowed these providers to operate despite broader disruption from telehealth companies, maintaining the industry's low concentration level.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage expenses are the largest cost
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Payroll expenses are the single-largest cost for behavioral therapy providers.

Workforce shortages are accelerating wage growth as practices vie to attract and retain qualified therapists and nonclinical staff. Solutions to the shortages of behavioral therapists are limited, sustaining wage growth moving forward.
Low provider reimbursement is a primary barrier to developing a robust behavioral health workforce.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Compliance and legal costs are steep
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Staying complicit with stringent federal regulations concerning reimbursement, billing management, insurance, telemedicine and patient safety creates considerable costs for therapy practices.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Behavioral therapy treatment is talk-based therapy between a therapist and a patient. So, even as new digital tools emerge, labor requirements will far exceed capital ones.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Mental health treatment can't be substituted
volatility_points.volatility_description: Behavioral therapists provide treatment for individuals struggling with mental health disorders (anxiety, phobias, addictions). Behavioral health treatment is...

volatility_points.volatility_title: Reliance on insurance reimbursements creates volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The extent of public and private insurance coverage of behavioral therapy treatment determines access to practitioners. Reimbursements from payors also influence revenue for providers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: COVID-19 exacerbated rates of mental health conditions
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Behavioral therapists use techniques and treatments to help patients struggling with mental and emotional conditions (anxiety, depression, panic disorder, phobias). According to the National Alliance on Mental Health (NAMI), 1 in 5 adults in the US is affected by a mental health condition. Depression is the most condition treated by therapists. The growing recognition of the importance of behavioral health services and expanding access to care through organizations and insurance plans is driving demand for these services. Demand for behavioral therapists has increased rapidly since COVID-19. The pandemic exacerbated preexisting mental health conditions following long periods of isolation and uncertainty, creating unprecedented support for stressor-related disorders, anxiety and depression.

FAQs.question: Has increased access to health insurance offered opportunities for your company?
FAQs.answer: As people have gained access to health insurance, demand for counseling has grown.

FAQs.question: How does your company market its services to the wider community?
FAQs.answer: Psychologists and behavioral therapists can better market themselves using digital platforms (referral networks, social media).

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need?
FAQs.answer: Therapists are usually based in areas with higher populations, such as metropolitan and suburban areas.

FAQs.question: How does an increase in certain age groups affect your company's performance?
FAQs.answer: Behavioral therapists employed by schools benefit from growth in the number of children and adolescents.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: Digital record-keeping software and online scheduling tools can make operations more efficient.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored offering telehealth services to improve patient accessibility and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Some counselors are able to meet with patients via video chat platforms.

FAQs.question: Have your regulatory expenses been impacted by federal healthcare reform?
FAQs.answer: Changes in Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement rates have impacted industry profit.

FAQs.question: Have any new mandates, as a result of healthcare reform, expanded your client base?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare reform increased the number of people with health insurance, causing demand for behavioral therapy services to rise.

FAQs.question: Has your company looked into financing options for low-income individuals and/or families?
FAQs.answer: Some counselors offer lower rates for low-income patients.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Financial performance is linked to the ability to access capital to fund expansion and growth.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: Behavioral health services are highly personal and, therefore, depend on clients feeling comfortable with their practitioner. A good reputation can assist in gaining referrals and customers.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Consumers prefer to access facilities close to their home, office, or school. Additionally, practitioners may locate close to hospitals and other healthcare professionals to increase referrals, making it more convenient for clients to visit.

FAQs.question: How have you dealt with negative effects of government policies? Do you discuss with clients how such policies can affect them?
FAQs.answer: Government policies affect practitioners' ability to operate in the industry. This should include an understanding of the effects of reimbursements on costs and income.

FAQs.question: Does demand for your business fluctuate with the divorce rate? What percentage of your patients are children with divorced parents?
FAQs.answer: Typically, as the divorce rate rises, so does demand for behavioral therapy. Studies indicate that children with divorced parents are more likely to have behavioral issues than children raised by married parents.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How do you stimulate demand when disposable income is low?
FAQs.answer: As per capita disposable income increases, more individuals have the discretionary income required to pay for behavioral therapy out-of-pocket.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your clients use Medicaid and Medicare? What payment do you receive from patients using Medicare or Medicaid?
FAQs.answer: As federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid rises, more individuals will have access to behavioral therapy.
